div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Baltimore Sun, September 27, 1900 [duplicate Box 3, Folder 65]
div1.p: DR. J. W. LAZEAR IS DEAD

Baltimorean Falls A Victim Of Yel-
low Fever In Havana.

News was received yesterday at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital from Surgeon-General
Sternberg of the death Tuesday night at
Havana, Cuba, from yellow fever of Dr.
Jesse W. Lazear, formerly on Prof. Wil-
liam Osler's staff at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, and one of the demonstrators of
clinical microscopy. He had given up his
position at the hospital in the spring to
undertake special work in the army in
Cuba, particularly in connection with the
problems relating to malaria and yellow
fever. He had charge of a laboratory in
one of the military hospitals in the neigh-
borhood of Havana.

Dr. Lazear was born in Baltimore in
1866. He was the son of William L. La-
zear, formerly a merchant in Exchange
Place, Baltimore, and grandson of Gen.
Jesse W. Lazear, a member of Congress
from Pennsylvania from 1864 to 1868, and
who subsequently purchased Windsor, in
the western suburbs of Baltimore, and
lived there until his death in 1877.

Dr. Lazear graduated from the Johns
Hopkins University in 1889 and from the
College of Physicians and Surgeons in New
York in 1892. After two years' work in
Bellevue Hospital he went to Berlin to
make a special study of bacteria. In 1895
he became one of the house physicians at
the Johns Hopkins Hospital and continued
the study of germ diseases.

Professor Osler says Dr. Lazear's death
is a very serious loss, as he was an ex-
ceptionally well-trained man and had al-
ready made some valuable studies on the
malarial parasites.

In 1895 Dr. Lazear married Miss Mabel
Houston, of California, whom he had met
abroad, and took up his residence in Park
avenue, Baltimore, and entered general
practice. Mrs. Lazear survives her hus-
band with two children--a son 2 years
old and a daughter 2 months old. They
are at present in Massachusetts, having
returned from Cuba in May. Dr. Lazear
was a member of the Phi Kappa Sigma
Fraternity of the Johns Hopkins Univer-
sity.
